name: Dumbbell Pullover
setup: Lie perpendicular across a flat bench with upper back supported
Hips below bench level, feet planted wide for stability
Hold one dumbbell with both hands under the top plate (diamond grip)
Start with dumbbell over chest, arms slightly bent (15-20° elbow angle)
steps: Inhale and lower dumbbell back overhead in an arc
Maintain slight elbow bend (don't straighten arms)
Lower until you feel a deep stretch in lats and chest (arms near ears)
Exhale and pull dumbbell back to start position using lats
Keep ribs down (avoid hyperextending lower back)
mistakes: Going too heavy (loses stretch, increases injury risk)
Rushing the eccentric (missing the stretch stimulus)
safety: Start light (20-30 lb) to learn the stretch position. Avoid if shoulder impingement present. Keep core engaged to protect lower back. If wrists are sensitive, use neutral-grip attachment or two dumbbells (one in each hand).

regressions: Reduce range of motion (stop at 45° overhead)
Lying on bench lengthwise (less stretch demand)
progressions: Increase range of motion (arms closer to ears)
Pause at stretch (3-5s hold at bottom)

prescriptionHints.load: 20-40 lb for hypertrophy; lighter than you think (stretch is the stimulus)
prescriptionHints.notes: Vertical pull pattern substitute when no pull-up bar available. Hits lats, serratus, chest, and core stability.

joints.notes: Maintain slight elbow bend to protect shoulder joint. Keep ribs down to avoid lower back hyperextension. Use diamond grip or two dumbbells if wrist discomfort.
